byline.contributor: Matt Furber reported from Minneapolis, and Richard Pérez-Peña from New York.
byline.original: By MATT FURBER and RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

abstract: Criminal complaints filed by attorney for Hennepin County, Minn, say Allen L Scarsella, white man accused of shooting five people during Black Lives protest in Minneapolis, has racist views and identifies himself as member of sovereign citizen movement, which refuses to recognize American government's authority; Scarsella was arrested with three others on day of shooting, and has been charged with five counts of second-degree assault, each punishable by up to 10 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: A white man accused of shooting five Black Lives Matter protesters in Minneapolis had racist views, according to criminal complaints filed Monday that charged him in the shooting and three others with related crimes.

headline.main: Four Charged in Shooting of Minneapolis Protesters
headline.print_headline: Four Charged in Shooting of Protesters in Minneapolis

snippet: A white man accused of shooting five Black Lives Matter protesters in Minneapolis had racist views, according to criminal complaints filed Monday that charged him in the shooting and three others with related crimes.
